greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of positive integers < n with the same number of 1's in their binary expansions as n.
comment: This sequence is related to the combinatorial number system:
- if n = Sum_{k=1..h} 2^c_k with 0 <= c_1 < c_2 < ... < c_h,
- then a(n) = Sum_{k=1..h} binomial(c_k, k) (with binomial(n, r) = 0 if n < r).
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: The binary expansion of 22 (10110) has 3 1's, as do those of the 6 smaller numbers 7, 11, 13, 14, 19 and 21, so a(22)=6.
program: (PARI) a(n) = my (v=0, k=0); for (c=0, oo, if (n==0, return (v), n%2, k++; if (c>=k, v+=c!/k!/(c-k)!)); n\=2) \\ _Rémy Sigrist_, Dec 23 2018
return sum([1 for i in range(n) if bin(i)[2:].count("1")==x]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, May 24 2017
xref: Cf. A067587, also A000120 for numerous references.
results.author: _Dean Hickerson_, Feb 16 2002
